— Mr. Clerk, Mr. Clerk.
sp.stage: [Goes to the Entrance to call the Clerk, the mean time Har. whips a Frock over himself, and puts down the hind part of the Chariot, and then 'tis a Cart.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What's the matter here?—

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Here's a Fellow, Sir, will perswade me, his Calash is a Cart, and refuses the Customs for passing the Gate.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: A Calash— Where?— I see only a Carter and his Cart.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Ha,— What a Devil, was I blind?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Mr. Clerk, I am a Baker, that come with Bread to sell, and this Fellow here has stopt me this hour, and made me lose the Sale of my Ware— and being Drunk, will out-face me I am a Farmer, and this Cart a Calash.—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: He's in an Errour Friend, pass on—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No Sir, I'll have satisfaction first, or the Vice-Roy shall know how he's serv'd by drunken Officers, that Nuisance to a Civil Government.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What do you demand, Friend?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Demand,— I demand a Crown, Sir.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: This is very hard— Mr. Clerk— If ever I saw in my Life, I thought I saw a Gentleman and a Calash.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Come, come, gratifie him, and see better hereafter.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Here Sir,— If I must, I must—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pass on, Friend—
sp.stage: [Ex. Clerk. Har. unseen, puts up the Back of his Calash, and whips off his Frock, and goes to drive on, The Officer looks on him, and stops him again.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Hum, I'll swear it is a Calash— Mr. Clerk,
Mr. Clerk, come back, come back—
sp.stage: [Runs out to call him. He changes as before.
sp.l: — Come Sir, let your own Eyes convince you, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Convince me, of what, you Sott?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: That this is a Gentleman, and that a— ha,—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Stark Drunk, Sirrah! if you trouble me at every Mistake of yours thus, you shall quit your Office.—

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, Sir, I am a little in Drink I confess, a little Blind and Mad— Sir,— This must be the Devil, that's certain.
sp.stage: [The Clerk goes out, Har. puts up his Calash again, and pulls off his Frock and drives out.
sp.p: — Well, now to my thinking, 'tis as plain a Calash again, as ever I saw in my Life, and yet I'm satisfy'd 'tis nothing but a Cart.

div.head: SCENE changes to the Doctors House. The Hall.

sp.stage: Enter Scaramouch in a Chair, which set down and open'd, on all sides, and on the top represents an Apothecaries Shop, the Inside being painted with Shelves and Rows of Pots and Bottles; Scaramouch sitting in it dress'd in Black, with a short black Cloak, a Ruff, and little Hat.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: THe Devil's in't, if either the Doctor, my Master, or Mopsophil, know me in this Disguise— And thus I may not only gain my Mistriss, and out-wit Harlequin, but deliver the Ladies those Letters from their Lovers, which I took out of his Pocket this Morning, and who wou'd suspect an Apothecary for a Pimp.— Nor can the Jade Mopsophil, in Honour, refuse a Person of my Gravity, and so well set up.—
— Hum, the Doctor here first, this is not so well, but I'm prepar'd with Impudence for all Encounters.
sp.stage: Enter the Doctor. Scaramouch Salutes him gravely.
sp.p: — Most Reverend Doctor Baliardo.—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Seignior—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I might, through great Pusillanimity, blush— to give you this Anxiety. Did I not opine you were as Gracious as Communitive and Eminent; and tho' you have no Cognisance of me, your Humble Servant,— yet I have of you,— you being so greatly sam'd for your admirable Skill, both in Gallenical and Paracelsian Phaenomena's, and other approv'd Felicities in Vulnerary Emeticks, and purgative Experiences.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Seignior,— your Opinion honours me— a rare Man this.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And though I am at present busied in writing— those few Observations I have accumulated in my Peregrinations, Sir, yet the Ambition I aspir'd to, of being an Ocular and Aurial Witness of your Singularity, made me trespass on your sublimer Affairs.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Seignior.—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: — Besides a violent Inclination, Sir, of being initiated into the Denomination of your Learned Family, by the Conjugal Circumference of a Matrimonial Tye, with that singularly accomplish'd Person— Madam, the Governante of your Hostel.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Hum— A sweet-heart for Mopsophil!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And if I may obtain your Condescension to my Hymenaeal Propositions, I doubt not my Operation with the Fair One.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Seignior, she is much honour'd in the Overture, and my Abilities shall not be wanting to fix the Concord.
— But have you been a Traveller, Sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Without Circumlocutions, Sir, I have seen all the Regions beneath the Sun and Moon.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Moon, Sir! You never travell'd thither, Sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p:
Not in Propria Persona, Seignior, but by speculation, I have, and made most considerable Remarques on
that incomparable Terra Firma, of which I have the compleatest Map in Christendom— and which Gonzales himself omitted in his Cosmographia of the Lunar Mundus.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: A Map of the Lunar Mundus, Sir! May I crave the Honour of seeing it?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You shall, Sir, together with a Map of Terra Incognita, a great Rarety, indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Jewels, Sir, worth a Kings Ransome.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha,— What Figure of a Thing have we here— Bantering my Credulous Uncle?— This must be some Scout sent from our Forlorn Hope, to discover the Enemy, and bring in fresh Intelligence.— Hum,— That Wink tipt me some Tidings, and she deserves not a good Look, who understands not the Language of the Eyes.— Sir, Dinner's on the Table.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Let it wait, I am imploy'd—
sp.stage: [She creeps to the other side of Scaramouch, who makes Signs with his Hand to her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha,— 'tis so,— This fellow has some Novel for us, some Letters or Instructions, but how to get it—
sp.stage: [As Scar. talks to the Doctor, he takes the Letters by degrees out of his Pocket, and unseen, gives 'em Bellemante behind him.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But this Map, Seignior; I protest you have fill'd me with Curiosity. Has it signify'd all things so exactly say you?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Omitted nothing, Seignior, no City, Town, Village or Villa; no Castle, River, Bridge, Lake, Spring or Mineral.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Are any, Sir, of those admirable Mineral Waters there, so frequent in our World?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: In abundance, Sir, the Famous Garamanteen, a young Italian, Sir, lately come from thence, gives an account of an excellent Scaturigo, that has lately made an Ebulation there, in great Reputation with the Lunary Ladies.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir! be pleas'd, Seignior, to solve me some Queries that may enode some apparences of the Virtue of the Water you speak of.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Pox upon him, what Questions he asks— but I must on— Why Sir, you must know,— the Tincture of this Water upon Stagnation, Ceruberates, and the Crocus upon the Stones Flaveces; this he observes— to be, Sir, the Indication of a Generous Water.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Hum—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Now, Sir, be pleas'd to observe the three Regions, if they be bright, without doubt Mars is powerful; if the middle Region or Camera be palled, Filia Solis is breeding.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And then the third Region, if the Faeces be volatil, the Birth will soon come in Balneo. This I observed also in the Laboratory of that Ingenious Chymist Lysidono, and with much Pleasure animadverted that Mineral of the same Zenith and Nader, of that now so famous Water in England, near that famous Metropolis, call'd Islington.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Seignior—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: For, Sir, upon the Infusion, the Crows Head immediately procures the Seal of Hermes, and had not Lac Virginis been too soon suck'd up, I believe we might have seen the Consummation of Amalgena.
sp.stage: [Bellemante having got her Letters, goes off. She makes Signs to him to stay a little. He Nods.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Most likely, Sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: But, Sir, this Garamanteen relates the strangest Operation of a Mineral in the Lunar World, that ever I heard of.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: As how, I pray, Sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Why, Sir, a Water impregnated to a Circulation with Fema Materia; upon my Honour, Sir, the strongest I ever drank of.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: How, Sir! did you drink of it?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I only speak the words of Garamanteen, Sir.
— Pox on him, I shall be trapt.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Cry Mercy, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The Lunary Physicians, Sir, call it Urinam Vulcani, it Calibrates every ones Excrements more or less according to the Gradus of the Natural Calor.— To my Knowledge, Sir, a Smith of a very fiery Constitution, is grown very Opulent by drinking these Waters.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: How, Sir, grown Rich by drinking the Waters, and to your Knowledge?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The Devil's in my Tongue, to my Knowledge, Sir, for what a man of Honour relates, I may safely affirm.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Excuse me, Seignior—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: For, Sir, conceive me how he grew Rich, since he drank those Waters he never buys any Iron, but hammers it out of Stercus Proprius.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis three a Clock, and Dinner will be cold.—
sp.stage: [Goes behind Scaramouch, and gives him the Note, and goes out.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I come Sweet-heart; but this is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, and if at any time Nature be too infirm, and he prove Costive, he has no more to do, but to apply a Load-stone ad Anum.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Most true, Sir, and that facilitates the Journey per Visera.— But I detain you, Sir, another time— Sir,— I will now only beg the Honour of a Word or two with the Governante, before I go.—.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sir, she shall wait on you, and I shall be proud of the Honour of your Conversation.—
sp.stage: Enter to him Harlequin, dress'd like a Farmer, as before.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Hum— What have we here, a Taylor or a Tumbler?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ha— Who's this?— Hum— What if it shou'd be the Farmer that the Doctor has promis'd Mopsophil to? My Heart misgives me.
sp.stage: [They look at each other a while.
sp.p: Who wou'd you speak with, Friend?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: This is, perhaps, my Rival, the Apothecary.— Speak with, Sir, why, what's that to you?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Have you Affairs with Seignior Doctor, Sir?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It may be I have, it may be I have not. What then, Sir?—
sp.stage: While they seem in angry Dispute, Enter Mopsophil.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Seignior Doctor tells me I have a Lover waits me, sure it must be the Farmer or the Apothecary. No matter which, so a Lover, that welcomest man alive. I am resolv'd to take the first good Offer, tho' but in Revenge of Harlequin and Scaramouch, for puting Tricks upon me.— Ha,— Two of'em!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: My Mistriss here!
sp.stage: [They both Bow and Advance, both putting each other by.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Hold Gentlemen,— do not worry me.
Which of you wou'd speak with me?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: I, I, I, Madam—

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Both of you?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: No, Madam, I, I.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: If both Lovers, you are both welcome, but let's have fair Play, and take your turns to speak.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ay, Seignior, 'tis most uncivil to interrupt me.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: And disingenious, Sir, to intrude on me.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Let me then speak first.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I'm Dumb.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I Acquiesce.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I was inform'd there was a Person here had Propositions of Marriage to make me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: That's I, that's I—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: And I attend to that consequential Finis.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I know not what you mean by your Finis, Seignior, but I am come to offer my self this Gentlewomans Servant, her Lover, her Husband, her Dog in a Halter, or any thing.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Him I pronounce a Paltroon, and an Ignominious Utensil, that dares lay claim to the Renowned Lady of my Primum Mobile; that is, my best Affections.—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I fear not your hard Words, Sir, but dare aloud pronounce, if Donna Mopsophil like me, the Farmer, as well as I like her, 'tis a Match, and my Chariot is ready at the Gate to bear her off, d'ye see.—

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Ah, how that Chariot pleads.—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And I pronounce, that being intoxicated with the sweet Eyes of this refulgent Lady, I come to tender her my noblest Particulars, being already most advantageously set up with the circumstantial Implements of my Occupation.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: A City Apothecary, a most Gentile Calling— Which shall I chuse?— Seignior Apothecary, I'll not expostulate the Circumstantial Reasons that have occasion'd me this Honour.—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Incomparable Lady, the Elegancy of your Repertees most excellently denote the Profundity of your Capacity.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What the Devil's all this? Good Mr. Conjurer stand by— and don't fright the Gentlewoman with your Elegant Profondities.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: How, a Conjurer! I will chastise thy vulgar Ignorance, that yelips a Philosopher a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Losaphers!— Prethee, if thou be'st a Man, speak like a Man— then

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Why, What do I speak like? What do I speak like?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What do you speak like— why you speak like a Wheel-Barrow.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: How!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And how.
sp.stage: [They come up close together at half Sword Parry; stare on each other for a while, then put up and bow to each other civilly.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Thats well Gentlemen, let's have all Peace, while I survey you both, and see which likes me best.
sp.stage: [She goes between 'em, and surveys 'em both, they making ridiculous Bows on both sides, and Grimaces the while.
sp.p: — ha,— now on my Conscience, my two foolish Lovers,— Harlequin and Scaramouch; how are my Hope's defeated?— but Faith I'll fit you both.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: So, she's considering still, I shall be the happy Dog.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: She's taking aim, she cannot chuse but like me best.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Well, Madam, how does my Person propagate.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Faith Seignior, now I look better on you, I do not like your Phisnomy so well as your Intellects; you discovering some Circumstantial Symptoms that ever denote a Villainous Inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Ah, you are pleas'd, Madam.—

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: You are mistaken, Seignior, I am displeas'd at your Gray Eyes, and Black Eye-brows and Beard, I never knew a Man with those Signs, true to his Mistriss or his Friend. And I wou'd sooner wed that Scoundrel Scaramouch, that very civil Pimp, that meer pair of Chymical Bellows that blow the Doctors projecting Fires, that Deputy-Urinal Shaker, that very Guzman of Salamanca, than a Fellow of your infallible Signum Mallis.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— you have your Answer, Seignior Friskin— and may shut up your Shop and be gone.— Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Hum, sure the Jade knows me—

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: And as for you, Seignior.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ha, Madam—

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p:
Those Lanthorn Jaws of yours, with that most villainous Sneer and Grin, and a certain fierce Aire of your Eyes, looks altogether most Fanatically— which with your notorious Whey Beard, are certain Signs of Knavery and Cowardice; therefore I'd rather wed that Spider Harlequin, that Sceliton Buffoon, that Ape of Man, that Jack of
Lent, that very Top, that's of no use, but when 'tis whipt and lasht, that pitious Property I'd rather wed than thee.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: A very fair Declaration—

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: you understand me— and so adieu sweet Glister-pipe, and Seignior dirty Boots, Ha, ha, ha.—
sp.stage: [They stand looking simply on each other, without speaking a while.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: That I shou'd not know that Rogue Harlequin.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: That I shou'd take this Fool for a Physician.
— How long have you commenc'd Apothecary, Seignior?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ever since you turn'd Farmer.—— Are not you a damn'd Rogue to put these Tricks upon me, and most dishonorably break all Articles between us?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And are not you a damn'd Son of a—— something— to break Articles with me?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No more Words, Sir, no more words, I find it must come to Action,— Draw.—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Draw,— so I can draw, Sir.——
sp.stage: They make a ridiculous cowardly Fight. Enter the Doctor, which they seeing, come on with more Courage. He runs between, and with his Cane beats the Swords down.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Hold— hold— What mean you Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Let me go, Sir, I am provok'd beyond measure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You must excuse me, Seignior—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I dare not discover the Fool for his Masters Sake, and it may spoil our Intrigue anon; besides, he'll then discover me, and I shall be discarded for bantering the Doctor.
— A Man of Honour to be so basely affronted here.——

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
Shou'd I discover this Rascal, he wou'd tell the Old Gentleman I was the same that attempted his House
to day in Womans Cloths, and I shou'd be kick'd and beaten most unsatiably.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What, Seignior, for a man of Parts to be impos'd upon,— and whipt through the Lungs here— like a Mountebanks Zany for sham Cures— Mr. Doctor, I must tell you 'tis not Civil.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I am extreamly sorry for it, Sir,— and you shall see how I will have this Fellow handled for the Affront to a Person of your Gravity, and in my House— Here Pedro,—
— Take this Intruder, or bring some of your Fellows hither, and toss him in a Blanket—
sp.stage: [Ex. Pedro. Har. going to creep away, Scar. holds him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Harkye,— bring me off, or I'll discover all your Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Let me alone—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'll warrant you some Rogue that has some Plot on my Neece and Daughter.—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, he comes to impose the grossest Lye upon you, that ever was heard of.
sp.stage: Enter Pedro with others, with a Blanket. They put Har. into it, and toss him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Hold, hold,— I'll confess all, rather than indure it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Hold,— What will you confess, Sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: — That he's the greatest Impostor in Nature. Wou'd you think it, Sir? he pretends to be no less than an Ambassador from the Emperor of the Moon, Sir—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ha,— Ambassador from the Emperor of the Moon—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, thereupon I laugh'd, thereupon he grew angry,— I laugh'd at his Resentment, and thereupon we drew— and this was the high Quarrel, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Hum,— Ambassador from the Moon.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I have brought you off, manage him as well as you can.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Brought me off, yes, out of the Frying-Pan into the Fire. Why, how the Devil shall I act an Ambassador?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: It must be so, for how shou'd either of these know I expected that Honour?
sp.stage: [He addresses him with profound Civility to Har.
sp.p: Sir, if the Figure you make, approaching so near ours of this World, have made us commit any undecent Indignity to your high Character, you ought to pardon the Frailty of our Mortal Education and Ignorance, having never before been blest with the Descention of any from your World.—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What the Devil shall I say now?

— I confess, I am as you see by my Garb, Sir, a little Incognito, because the Publick Message I bring, is very private— which is, that the mighty Iredonozor, Emperor of the Moon— with his most worthy Brother, the Prince of Thunderland, intend to Sup with you to Night— Therefore be sure you get good Wine.— Tho' by the way let me tell you, 'tis for the Sake of your Fair Daughter.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I'll leave the Rogue to his own Management.— I presume, by your whispering, Sir, you wou'd be private, and humbly beging Pardon, take my Leave.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You have it Friend. Does your Neece and Daughter Drink, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Drink, Sir?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ay, Sir, Drink hard.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Do the Women of your World drink hard, Sir?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: According to their Quality, Sir, more or less; the greater the Quality, the more Profuse the Quantity.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why that's just as 'tis here; but your Men of Quality, your States-men, Sir, I presume they are Sober, Learned and Wise.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Faith, no, Sir, but they are, for the most part, what's as good, very Proud, and promising, Sir, most liberal of their Word to every fauning Suiter, to purchase the state of long Attendance, and cringing as they pass; but the Devil of a Performance, without you get the Knack of bribing in the right Place and Time; but yet they all defy it, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Just, just as 'tis here.
— But pray Sir, How do these Great Men live with their Wives.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Most Nobly, Sir, my Lord keeps his Coach, my Lady, hers; my Lord his Bed, my Lady hers; and very rarely see one another, unless they chance to meet in a Visit, in the Park, the Mall, the Toore, or at the Basset-Table, where they civilly Salute and part, he to his Mistriss, she to play.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Good lack! just as 'tis here.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: — Where, if she chance to lose her Money, rather than give out, she borrows of the next Amorous Coxcomb, who, from that Minute, hopes, and is sure to be paid again one way or other, the next kind Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: — Just as 'tis here.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: As for the young Fellows that have Money, they have no Mercy upon their own Persons, but wearing Nature off as fast as they can, Swear, and Whore and Drink, and Borrow as long any Rooking Citizen will lend, till having dearly purchased the Heroick Title of a Bully or a Sharper, they live pity'd of their Friends, and despis'd by their Whores, and depart this Transitory World, diverse and sundry ways.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Just, just, as 'tis here!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: As for the Citizen, Sir, the Courtier lies with his Wife, he, in revenge, cheats him of his Estate, till Rich enough to marry his Daughter to a Courtier, again give him all— unless his Wives Over-Gallantry break him; and thus the World runs round.——

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: The very same 'tis here.— Is there no preserment, Sir, for Men of Parts and Merit?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Parts and Merit! What's that? a Livery, or the handsome tying a Cravat, for the great Men prefer none but their Foot-men and Vallets.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: By my Troth, just as 'tis here.
— Sir, I find you are a Person of most profound Intelligence— under Favour, Sir,— Are you a Native of the Moon or this World.—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The Devils in him for hard Questions.
— I am a Naopolitan, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sir, I Honour you; good luck, my Countryman!
How got you to the Region of the Moon, Sir?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: — A plaguy inquisitive old Fool—
— Why, Sir,— Pox on't, what shall I say?— I being— one day in a musing Melancholy, walking by the Sea-side— there arose, Sir, a great Mist, by the Suns exhaling of the Vapours of the Earth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: In this Fog or Mist, Sir, I was exhal'd.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: The Exalations of the Sun, draw you to the Moon, Sir?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am condemn'd to the Blanket again.— I say, Sir, I was exhal'd up, but in my way— being too heavy, was dropt into the Sea.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: How, Sir, into the Sea?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The Sea, Sir, where the Emperors Fisher-man casting his Nets, drew me up, and took me for a strange and monstrous Fish, Sir,— and as such, presented me to his Mightiness,— who going to have me Spitchcock'd for his own eating.—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: How, Sir, eating?—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What did me I, Sir, (Life being sweet) but fall on my Knees, and besought his Gloriousness not to eat me, for I was no Fish but a Man; he ask'd me of what Country, I told him of Naples; whereupon the Emperor overjoy'd ask'd me if I knew that most Reverend and most Learned Doctor Baliardo, and his fair Daughter. I told him I did: whereupon he made me his Bed-fellow, and the Confident to his Amour to Seigniora Elaria.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Bless me, Sir! how came the Emperor to know my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: — There he is again with his damn'd hard Questions.— Knew her, Sir,— Why— you were walking abroad one day.—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: My Daughter never goes abroad, Sir, farther than our Garden.—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ay, there it was indeed, Sir,— and as his Highness was taking a Survey of this lower World— through a long Perspective, Sir,— he saw you and your Daughter and Neece, and from that very moment, fell most desperately in Love.— But hark— the sound of Timbrils, Kettle-Drums and Trumpets.— The Emperor, Sir, is on his Way,— prepare for his Reception.
sp.stage: [A strange Noise is heard of Brass Kettles, and Pans, and Bells, and many tinkling things.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'm in a Rapture— How shall I pay my Gratitude for this great Negotiation?— but as I may, I humbly offer, Sir.—
sp.stage: [Presents him with a Rich Ring and a Purse of Gold.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir, as an Honour done the Emperor, I take your Ring and Gold. I must go meet his Highness.—
sp.stage: Enter to him Scaramouch, as himself.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! we are astonish'd with the dreadful sound of the sweetest Musick that ever Mortal heard, but know not whence it comes. Have you not heard it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Heard it, yes, Fool,— 'Tis the Musick of the Spheres, the Emperor of the Moon World is descending.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: How, Sir, no marvel then, that looking towards the South, I saw such splendid Glories in the Air.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Ha,— saw'st thou ought descending in the Air?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Sir, Wonders! haste to the old Gallery, whence, with the help of your Telescope, you may discover all.—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I wou'd not lose a moment for the lower Universe.
sp.stage: Enter Elaria, Bellemante, Mopsophil, dress'd in rich Antick Habits.

sp.speaker: Ela.
sp.p: Sir, we are dress'd as you commanded us, What is your farther Pleasure?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: — It well becomes the Honour you're design'd for, this Night to wed two Princes— come with me and know your happy Fates.

sp.speaker: Ela.
sp.p: Bless me! My Father, in all the rest of his Discourse, shows so much Sense and Reason, I cannot think him mad, but feigns all this to try us.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not Mad! Marry Heaven forbid, thou art always creating Fears to startle one; why, if he be not mad, his want of Sleep this eight and forty hours, the Noise of strange unheard of Instruments, with the Fantastick Splendor of the unusual Sight, will so turn his Brain and dazle him, that in Grace of Goodness, he may be Mad: If he be not;— come, let's after him to the Gallery, for I long to see in what showing Equipage our Princely Lovers will address to us.

div.head: SCENE The Last. The Gallery richly adorn'd with Scenes and Lights.

sp.stage: Enter Doctor, Elaria, Bellemante, and Mopsophil. Soft Musick is heard.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: HA— Heavens! what's here?— what Palace is this?— No part of our House, I'm sure.—

sp.speaker: Ela.
sp.l: 'Tis rather the Apartment of some Monarch.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'm all amazement too, but must not show my Ignorance.— Yes, Elaria, this is prepar'd to entertain two Princes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Are you sure on't, Sir? are we not, think you, in that World above, I often heard you speak of? in the Moon, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: How shall I resolve her?— For ought I know, we are.

sp.speaker: Ela.
sp.l: Sure, Sir, 'tis some Inchantment.

sp.speaker: Doct
sp.p: Let not thy Female Ignorance prophane the highest Mysteries of Natural Philosophy: To Fools it seems Inchantment— but I've a Sense can reach it,— sit and expect the Event.— Hark— I am amaz'd, but must conceal my Wonder— that Joy of Fools— and appear wise in Gravity.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Whence comes this charming Sound, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: From the Spheres— it is familiar to me.
sp.stage: The Scene in the Front draws off, and shews the Hill of Parnassus; a noble large Walk of Trees leading to it, with eight or ten Negroes upon Pedestals, rang'd on each side of the Walks. Next Keplair and Gallileus descend on each side, opposite to each other, in Chariots, with Perspectives in their Hands, as viewing the Machine of the Zodiack. Soft Musick plays still.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Methought I saw the Figure of two Men descend from yonder Cloud, on yonder Hill.

sp.speaker: Ela.
sp.p: I thought so too, but they are disappear'd, and the wing'd Chariot's fled.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: See, Sir, they approach.—

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Most Reverend Sir, we, from the upper World, thus low salute you.— Keplair and Gallileus we are call'd, sent as Interpreters to Great Iredonozor, the Emperor of the Moon, who is descending.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Most Reverend Bards— profound Philosophers— thus low I bow to pay my humble Gratitude.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: The Emperor, Sir, salutes you, and your fair Daughter.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And, Sir, the Prince of Thunderland salutes you, and your fair Neece.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Thus low I fall to thank their Royal Goodness.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Came you, most Reverend Bards, from the Moon World?

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.l: Most Lovely Maid, we did.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: May I presume to ask the manner how?

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: By Cloud, Sir, through the Regions of the Air, down to the fam'd Parnassus; thence by Water, along the River Helicon, the rest by Post, upon two wing'd Eagles.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sir, are there store of our World inhabiting the Moon?

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Oh, of all Nations, Sir, that lie beneath it in the Emperors Train! Sir, you will behold abundance; look up and see the Orbal World descending; observe the Zodiack, Sir, with her twelve Signs.
sp.stage: [Next the Zodiack descends, a Symphony playing all the while; when it is landed, it delivers the twelve Signs: Then the Song, the Persons of the Zodiack being the Singers. After which, the Negroes Dance and mingle in the Chorus.

lg.head: A Song for the Zodiack.
lg.l: LET murmuring Lovers no longer Repine,
But their Hearts and their Voices advance;
Let the Nimphs and the Swains in the kind Chorus joyn,
And the Satyrs and Fauns in a Dance.
Let nature put on her Beauty of May,
And the Fields and the Meadows adorn;
Let the Woods and the Mountains resound with the Joy,
And the Echoes their Triumph return.
For since Love wore his Darts,
And Virgins grew Coy;
Since these wounded Hearts,
And those cou'd destroy.
There ne'er was more Cause for your Triumphs and Joy.
Hark, bark, the Musick of the Spheres,
Some Wonder approaching declares;
Such, such, as has not blest your Eyes and Ears
This thousand, thousand, thousand years.
See, see what the Force of Love can make,
Who rules in Heaven, in Earth and Sea;
Behold how he commands the Zodiack,
While the fixt Signs unhinging all obey.
Not one of which, but represents
The Attributes of Love,
Who governs all the Elements
In Harmony above.
For since Love wore his Darts,
And Virgins grew Coy;
Since these wounded Hearts,
And those cou'd destroy,
There ne'er was more Cause for your Triumphs and Joy.
The wanton Aries first descends,
To show the Vigor and the Play,
Beginning Love, beginning Love attends,
When the young Passion is all-over Joy,
He bleats his soft Pain to the fair curled Throng,
And he leaps, and he bounds, and Loves all the day long.
At once Loves Courage and his Slavery
In Taurus is express'd,
Tho' o're the Plains he Conqueror be,
The Generous Beast
Does to the Yoak submit his Noble Breast,
While Gemini smiling and twining of Arms,
Shows Loves soft Indearments and Charms.
And Cancer's slow Motion the degrees do express,
Respectful Love arrives to Happiness.
Leo his Strength and Majesty,
Virgo his blushing Modesty,
And Libra all his Equity.
His Subtilty does Scorpio show,
And Sagittarius all his loose desire,
By Capricorn his forward Humour know,
And Aqua. Lovers Tears that raise his Fire,
While Pisces, which intwin'd do move,
Show the soft Play, and wanton Arts of Love.

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: For since Love wore his Darts,
And Virgins grew Coy;
Since these wounded Hearts,
And those cou'd destroy,
There ne'er was more Cause for Triumphs and Joy:

sp.p: — See how she turns, and sends her Signs to Earth.— Behold the Ram— Aries— see Taurus next descends; then Gemini— see how the Boys embrace— Next Cancer, then Leo, then the Virgin; next to her Libra— Scorpio, Sagittary, Capricorn, Aquarius,— Pisces. This eight thousand years no Emperor has descended, but Incognito, but when he does, to make his Journey more Magnificent, the Zodiack, Sir, attends him.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: 'Tis all amazing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Now, Sir, behold, the Globick World descends two thousand Leagues below its wonted Station, to show Obedience to its proper Monarch.
sp.stage: [After which, the Globe of the Moon appears, first, like a new Moon; as it moves forward it increases, till it comes to the Full. When it is descended, it opens, and shews the Emperor and the Prince. They come forth with all their Train, the Flutes playing a Symphony before him, which prepares the Song. Which ended, the Dancers mingle as before.

lg.l: ALL Joy to Mortals, Joy and Mirth
Eternal IO'S sing;
The Gods of Love descend to Earth,
Their Darts have lost the Sting.
The Youth shall now complain no more
On Silvia's needless Scorn,
But she shall love, if he adore,
And melt when he shall burn.
The Nimph no longer shall be shy,
But leave the jilting Road;
And Daphne now no more shall fly
The wounded panting God;
But all shall be serene and fair,
No sad Complaints of Love
Shall fill the Gentle whispering Air,
No echoing Sighs the Grove.
Beneath the Shades young Strephon lies,
Of all his Wish possess'd;
Gazing on Silvia's charming Eyes,
Whose Soul is there confess'd.
All soft and sweet the Maid appears,
With Looks that know no Art,
And though she yields with trembling Fears,
She yields with all her Heart.

sp.p: — See, Sir, the Cloud of Foreigners appears, French, English, Spaniards, Danes, Turks, Russians, Indians, and the nearer Climes of Christendom; and lastly, Sir, behold the mighty Emperor.—
sp.stage: [A Chariot appears, made like a Half Moon, in which is Cinthio for the Emperor, richly dress'd and Charmante for the Prince, rich, with a good many Heroes attending. Cinthio's Train born by four Cupids. The Song continues while they descend and land. They address themselves to Elaria and Bellemante.— Doctor fallson his Face, the rest bow very low as they pass. They make signs to Keplair.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: The Emperor wou'd have you rise, Sir, he will expect no Ceremony from the Father of his Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I cannot, Sir, behold his Mightiness— the Splendor of his Majesty confounds me—

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.l: You must be moderate, Sir, it is expected.
sp.stage: [The two Lovers make all the Signs of Love in dumb show to the Ladies, while the soft Musick plays again from the End of the Song.—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Shall I not have the Joy to hear their Heavenly Voices, Sir?

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: They never speak to any Subject, Sir, when they appear in Royalty, but by Interpreters, and that by way of Stentraphon, in manner of the Delphick Oracles.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Any way, so I may hear the Sence of what they wou'd say.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: No doubt you will— But see the Emperor commands by signs his Foreigners to dance—
sp.stage: [A very Antick Dance. The Dance ended, the Front Scene draws off, and shows a Temple, with an Altar, one speaking thorugh a Stentraphon from behind it. Soft Musick plays the while.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Most Learned Sir, the Emperor now is going to declare himself, according to his Custom, to his Subjects. Listen.—

sp.speaker: Sten.
sp.l: Most Reverend Sir, whose Vertue did incite us,
Whose Daughters Charms did more invite us;
We come to grace her with that Honour,
That never Mortal yet had done her,
Once only, Jove was known in Story,
To visit Semele in Glory.
But fatal 'twas, he so enjoy'd her,
Her own ambitious Flame destroy'd her.
His Charms too fierce for Flesh and Blood,
She dy'd embracing of her God.
We gentler marks of Passion give,
The Maid we love, shall love and live;
Whom visibly we thus will grace,
Above the rest of human Race.
Say, is't your Will that we shou'd Wed her,
And nightly in Disguises Bed her.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: The Glory is too great for Mortal Wife.

sp.speaker: Sten.
sp.l: What then remains, but that we consummate
This happy Marriage in our splendid State?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Thus low I kneel, in thanks for this great Blessing.
sp.stage: [Cinthio takes Elaria by the Hand; Charmante, Bellemante; two of the Singers in white being Priests, they lead'em to the Altar, the whole Company dividing one either side. Where, while a Hymeneal Song is sung, the Priest joyns their Hands. The Song ended, and they Marry'd, they come forth; but before they come forward,— two Chariots descend, one on one side above, and the other on the other side; in which, is Harlequin dress'd like a Mock Hero, with others, and Scaramouch in the other, dress'd so in Helmets.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Stay mighty Emperor, and vouchsafe to be the Umpire of our Difference.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Two neighbouring Princes to your vast Dominion.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Knights of the Sun, our Honourable Titles.
And fight for that fair Mortal, Mopsophil.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Bless us!— my two precious Lovers, I'll warrant; well, I had better take up with one of them, than lye alone to Night.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Long as two Rivals we have Lov'd and Hop'd,
Both equally endeavour'd, and both fail'd.
At last by joynt Consent, we both agreed
To try our Titles by the Dint of Lance,
And chose your Mightiness for Arbitrator.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.l: The Emperor gives Consent.—
sp.stage: [They both, all arm'd with gilded Lances and Shields of Black, with Golden Suns painted. The Musick plays a fighting Tune. They fight at Barriers, to the Tune.— Harlequin is often Foil'd, but advances still; at last Scaramouch throws him, and is Conqueror; all give Judgment for him.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.l: The Emperor pronounces you are Victor.—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Receive your Mistriss, Sir, as the Reward of your undoubted Valour—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Sir, and Scaramouch, returns you humble Thanks.—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ha,— Scaramouch—
sp.stage: [Bawls out, and falls in a Chair. They all go to him.
sp.p: My Heart misgives me— Oh, I am undone and cheated every way.—

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.l: Be patient, Sir, and call up all your Vertue,
You're only cur'd, Sir, of a Disease
That long has raign'd over your Nobler Faculties.
Sir, I am your Physician, Friend and Counsellor;
It was not in the Power of Herbs or Minerals,
Of Reason, common Sense, and right Religion,
To draw you from an Error that unman'd you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I will be Patient, Gentlemen, and hear you.
— Are not you Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.l: I am,— and these are Gentlemen of Quality,
That long have lov'd your Daughter and your Neece.
Don Cinthio this, and this Don Charmante,
The Vice-Roys Nephews, both.——
Who found as men— 'twas impossible to enjoy 'em,
And therefore try'd this Stratagem.—

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you, mitigate your Grief,
Altho' indeed we are but mortal men,
Yet we shall Love you,— Serve you, and obey you—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Are not you then the Emperor of the Moon?
And you the Prince of Thunderland?

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.l: There's no such Person, Sir.
These Stories are the Fantoms of mad Brains,
To puzzle Fools withal— the Wise laugh at 'em,—
— Come Sir, you shall no longer be impos'd upon.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: No Emperor of the Moon,— and no Moon World!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Rediculous Inventions.
If we'd not lov'd you, you'd been still impos'd on;
We had brought a Scandal on your Learned Name,
And all succeeding Ages had despis'd it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Burn all my Books, and let my Study Blaze,
Burn all to Ashes, and be sure the Wind
Scatter the vile Contagious Monstrous Leys.

— Most Noble Youths— you've honour'd me with your Alliance, and you, and all your Friends, Assistances in this Glorious Miracle, I invite to Night to revel with me.— Come all and see my happy Recantation of all the Follies Fables have inspir'd till now. Be pleasant to repeat your Story, to tell me by what kind degrees you Cozen'd me—
I see there's nothing in Philosophy—
Of all that writ, he was the wisest Bard, who spoke this mighty Truth.— He that knew all that ever Learning writ, Knew only this— that he knew nothing yet.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.byline: To be spoken by Mrs. Cooke.

lg.l: WIth our old Plays, as with dull Wife it fares,
To whom you have been marry'd tedious years.
You Cry— She's wondrous good, it is confess'd,
But still 'tis Chapon Boüillé at the best;
That constant Dish can never make a Feast:
Yet the pall'd Pleasure you must still purste,
You give so small incouragement for new;
And who wou'd drudge for such a wretched Age?
Who want the Bravery, to support one Stage.
The wiser Wits have now new Measures set,
And taken up new Trades, that they may haue,
No more your nice fantastick pleasures serve,
Your Pimps you pay, but let your Poets starve.
They long in vain, for better Usage hop'd,
Till quite undone and tir'd, they dropt and dropt;
Not one is left will write for thin third day,
Like desperate Pickeroons, no Prize no Pay;
And when they've done their best, the Recompence,
Is, Dam the Sot, his Play wants common Sense.
Ill natur'd wits, who can so ill requite
The Drudging Slaves, who for your, Pleasure write.
Look back on flourishing Rome, ye proud Ingrates,
And see how she her thriving Poets treats:
Wisely she priz'd 'em at the noblest Rate,
As necessary Ministers of State,
And contributions rais'd to make 'em great.
They from the publick Bank she did maintain,
And freed from want, they only writ for Fame;
And were as useful in a City held,
As formidable Armies in the Field.
They but a Conquest over Men pursu'd,
While these by gentler force the Soul subdu'd.
Not Rome in all her happiest Pomp cou'd show
A greater Caesar than we boast of now;
Augustus Reigns, but Poets still are low.
May Caesar live, and while his Mighty Hand
Is Scattering Plenty over all the Land;
With God like Bounty recompencing all,
Some fruitful drops may on the Muses fall;
Since honest Pens do his just cause afford
Equal Advantage with the useful Sword.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
